markdown: It is noted that the Department of Nutrition of the University of Valle, in conjunction with the Harvard School of Public Health, is presently studying the development of food protein supplements from locally grown vegetable products. The essential functions of such a food research institute and needs of a food laboratory are listed in Appendix IV. This list should be con- sidered minimal. Other equipment would be found necessary as research programs develop. 10. A School of Home Economics should be established, possibly within the National University, to provide graduates for youth work, school programs and home demonstration projects in conjunction with the program in nutrition edu- cation. 11. Training of agricultural scientists should be encouraged and expanded. 12. Better coordination of existing agricultural development programs, official and semiofficial, should be established. 13. Attention should be given to strengthening public confidence in quality control and enforcement programs for feeds, fertilizers and agricultural chemicals by vigorous administration of present policies and extension of these policies where needed to assure provision of reliable sources of agricultural supplies. 14. The food processing industry should be strengthened by: a. The development of quality grading systems for raw products as a basis for purchases and payment. Such standards create an incentive for production of high quality by producers. b. Establishment of effective Government regulations for purity of processed foods. Safe, wholesome food is important for the health of the people as well as for the protection of reputable producers. c. Development of a can manufacturing industry, which would re- lieve the food processors of such problems as obtaining tin plate, fabricating and enameling cans, obtaining proper closures, etc.1/ d. The construction of additional processing and storage facilities near the source of raw material supplies. For example, the establishment of meat processing plants in the areas of cattle production would eliminate great losses in quantity and quality of meat incurred during transportation to market. Investment of capital in equipment for the catching, freezing and canning of fish should be encouraged in order to take advantage of the abundant supply of this great food resource in Colombia. 1/ In March of 1961 the American Can Company announced its plans to establish a factory for the production of cans in Barranquilla. 32 Source: https://www.industrydocuments.ucsf.edu/docs/nxyc0227 FIGURE 1 <::MAPA DE LA REPUBLICA DE COLOMBIA 1957 Elaborado por el INSTITUTO GEOGRAFICO DE COLOMBIA "Agustin Codazzi" para el Instituto Colombiano de Opinión Pública. ESCALA 1:5000000 CONVENCIONES: Capital de la República: [star symbol] Capital de Departamento: [square symbol] Poblaciones: [circle symbol] Ferrocarriles: [dashed line with cross symbol] Carreteras: [solid line] Limite Internacional: [dashed line with dots] Limite Departamental: [dashed line] Map of Colombia showing departments, major cities, rivers, and neighboring countries. The map includes latitude and longitude grid lines. **Neighboring Countries:** PANAMA ECUADOR PERU BRASIL VENEZUELA **Oceans:** OCEANO PACIFICO OCEANO ATLANTICO **Departments/Regions and Major Cities (partial list):** GUAJIRA: RIOHACHA, Uribia MAGDALENA: SANTA MARTA, Cienaga, Fundación, Valledupar ATLANTICO: BARRANQUILLA, Soledad, Sabanalarga BOLIVAR: CARTAGENA, Salamina, Calamar, Zambrano, El Carmen, Lorica, Corozal, Magangue, El Banco NORTE DE SANTANDER: Gamarra, Ocaña, Abrego, CUCUTA, Pamplona SANTANDER: Puerto Berrio, P to Wilches, BUCARAMANGA, Barrancabermeja, San Gil, Socorro, Soata, Barbos, Sonson ARAUCA: Arauca, PTO CARREÑO BOYACA: Paz de Rio, Duitama, Sogamoso, Villapinzón, Pajarito, Orocué VICHADA META: San Martin, Colombia, VILLAVICENCIO VAUPES: MITU AMAZONAS: LETICIA PUTUMAYO: Tres Esquinas, Lo Tagua, Puerto Asís CAQUETA: Florencia NARIÑO: Tumaco, Barbacoas, Patia, San Agustin, La Union, PASTO, MOCDA, ipiales CAUCA: Guapi, Caloto, Santander, POPAYAN, La Plata, Garzón VALLE: Buenaventura, CALI, Buga, Pradera TOLIMA: IBAGUE, Chaparral, Girardot, Fusagasugá CUNDINAMARCA: MANIZALES, Armero, Paquirá, Cartago, Pereira, Sta. Rosa de Cracatativa, Dorada, Pto Salgar, BOGOTA, Tocaima, Caqueza, Caicedonia CALDAS: Itsmina, Chiquinquirá, TUNJA, Tota ANTIOQUIA: Riosucio, Juradó, Turbo, Antioquia, Cisneros, MEDELLIN, Itagüí, Fredonia CHOCO: QUIBDO CORDOBA: Sahagún, MONTERIA, Sucre, Planeta, Caceres **Rivers (partial list):** RIO MAGDALENA RIO CAUCA RIO META RIO ARAUCA RIO GUAIVIA RIO VAUPES RIO CAQUETA RIO PUTUMAYO RIO AMAZONAS RIO GUAVIARE RIO ORINOCO RIO NEGRO RIO LEGUIZAMO **Islands/Banks (near Venezuela):** Banco Alicia Bajo nuevo Banco de Serranilla Banco de Quitasueño Banco de Serrana Cayos de Roncador I. de Providencia I. de San Andrés Cayos del E.S.E. chunks.markdown: It is noted that the Department of Nutrition of the University of Valle, in conjunction with the Harvard School of Public Health, is presently studying the development of food protein supplements from locally grown vegetable products.

The essential functions of such a food research institute and needs of a food laboratory are listed in Appendix IV. This list should be con- sidered minimal. Other equipment would be found necessary as research programs develop.

10. A School of Home Economics should be established, possibly within the National University, to provide graduates for youth work, school programs and home demonstration projects in conjunction with the program in nutrition edu- cation.
11. Training of agricultural scientists should be encouraged and expanded.
12. Better coordination of existing agricultural development programs, official and semiofficial, should be established.

13. Attention should be given to strengthening public confidence in quality control and enforcement programs for feeds, fertilizers and agricultural chemicals by vigorous administration of present policies and extension of these policies where needed to assure provision of reliable sources of agricultural supplies.

14. The food processing industry should be strengthened by: a. The development of quality grading systems for raw products as a basis for purchases and payment. Such standards create an incentive for production of high quality by producers.

b. Establishment of effective Government regulations for purity of processed foods. Safe, wholesome food is important for the health of the people as well as for the protection of reputable producers.
c. Development of a can manufacturing industry, which would re- lieve the food processors of such problems as obtaining tin plate, fabricating and enameling cans, obtaining proper closures, etc.1/

d. The construction of additional processing and storage facilities near the source of raw material supplies. For example, the establishment of meat processing plants in the areas of cattle production would eliminate great losses in quantity and quality of meat incurred during transportation to market. Investment of capital in equipment for the catching, freezing and canning of fish should be encouraged in order to take advantage of the abundant supply of this great food resource in Colombia.
1/ In March of 1961 the American Can Company announced its plans to establish a factory for the production of cans in Barranquilla.
